bibl.title: Telegram from Philip Showalter Hench to Currier McEwen, September 12, [1951]

div1.p: Hench sends a message honoring the memory of Reed on the 100th anniversary of his birth, to be read at the New York University College of Medicine celebration.

div1.head: Telegram from Philip Showalter Hench to Currier McEwen, September 12, [1951]
div1.opener:
Y F
C O P Y
WESTERN
UNION
1206
W. P. MARSHALL, PRESIDENT
Send the following message, subject to the terms on back hereof, which are hereby agreed to
DR. CURRIER MCEWEN, DEAN OF NEW YORK UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF MEDICINE 477 FIRST AVE.
NEW YORK CITY, NEW YORK.
div1.p:
I REGRET GREATLY THAT I CANNOT PERSONALLY JOIN YOU AND YOUR COLLEAGUES IN
HONORING THE MEMORY OF WALTER REED DISTINGUISHED ALUMNUS OF OLD BELLEVUE
HOSPITAL MEDICAL COLLEGE ON THE HUNDREDTH ANNIVERSARY OF THIS BIRTHDAY. ON
HIS DEATH-BED HE REGRETFULLY TOLD HIS OLD FRIEND GENERAL KEAN: “I AM LEAV-
ING MY FAMILY SO LITTLE-SO LITTLE.”

TIME HAS SHOWN THAT HIS HUMBLE APPRAISAL OF HIS ESTATE WAS ONE OF THE GREATEST
UNDER-EVALUATIONS OF HISTORY. BY CONTROLLING ONE of the GREAT PLAGUES HE LEFT
THE WORLD'S FAMILY AT LARGE A PRICELESS HERITAGE. LONG FREE OF YELLOW
FEVER, THE SAFFRON HORROR, NEW YORK AND OTHER GREAT AMERICAN PORTS OWE HIMM
AND HIS ASSOCIATES THEIR LASTING GRATITUDE. REGARDLESS OF THEORIES OR
THEIR SPONSORS REED SOUGHT AND DISCOVERED THE TRUTH. WITH CHARACTERISTIC
FAIRNESS HE ACKNOWLEDGED HIS INDEBTEDNESS TO FINLAY, LAZEAR, OTHER ADVISORS
AND ASSOCIATES. WITH HUMILITY AT THE MOMENT OF SUCCESS HE THANKED HIS GOD
FOR HAVING BEEN PERMITTED TO ATTAIN HIS LIFE-LONG WISH “IN SOME WAY OR SOME
TIME TO DO SOMETHING TO ALLEVIATE HUMAN SUFFERING.” LET HIS PRAYERFUL
WISH BE OURS. LET US, TODAYS STUDENTS OF MEDICAL SCIENCE, FOLLOW HIS EXAMPLE
AND THUS WORTHILY HONOR THE PRINCIPLES OF WALTER REED.
